sect3.title: Goals
sect3.para: The MATE Documentation Project (GDP) aims to provide MATE and MATE applications with a complete, intuitive, and clear documentation system. At the center of the GDP is Yelp, which presents a unified interface to MATE-specific documentation as well as other Linux documentation such as man pages and texinfo documents. The MATE Help System provides a comprehensive view of documentation on a machine by dynamically assembling the documentation of MATE applications and components which are installed. The GDP is responsible for writing numerous MATE-related documents for users. User documentation include the MATE User's Guide, the MATE Release Notes, and MATE application documentation. Most MATE applications have their own manual in addition to context sensitive help.

sect3.title: Joining the GDP
sect3.para:
Documenting MATE and all the numerous MATE applications is a very large project. The GDP is always looking for people to help write, update, and edit documentation. If you are interested in joining the GDP team, you should join the
mate-doc-list mailing list . Read , for help selecting a project to work on. Feel free to introduce yourself on the mate-doc-list mailing list and indicate which project you intend to work on, or else ask for suggestions of important documents which need work done. You may also want to join the #docs IRC channel on irc.mate.org to meet other GDP members and discuss any questions you may have. For a list of GDP projects and members, see the
GDP Website.

sect3.title: Collaborating with the GDP
sect3.para: MATE developers, packagers, and translators may not be writing MATE documentation but will want to understand how the MATE documentation system works and will need to collaborate with GDP members. This document should help to outline the structure of how the MATE documentation system works. Developers who do not write the documentation for their applications are encouraged to find a GDP member to write the documentation. This is best done by sending an email to the mate-doc-list mailing list describing the application, where it can be downloaded from, and that the developer(s) would like a GDP member to write documentation for the application. The #docs IRC channel on irc.mate.org is another option for contacting GDP members.

sect2.title: Notation and Conventions
sect2.para:
This Handbook uses the following notation:
/usr/bin
Directory
foo.sgml
Filename
command
Command or text that would be typed.
replaceable
"Variable" text that can be replaced.
Program or Doc Code
Program or document code

sect2.title: About this Handbook
sect2.para: This Handbook is a guide for both writing user documentation for MATE components and applications and for properly binding and packaging documentation into MATE applications.
This Handbook is not a guide for writing developer documentation. If you can read C and wish to write developer documentation take a look at GTK+ Reference Documentation Project.

This Handbook, like all MATE documentation, was written in DocBook(XML) and is available in several formats including XML, HTML, PostScript, and PDF. For the latest version, see
MATE Handbook of Writing Software Documentation . Alternately, one may download it anonymously from MATE SVN under mate-devel-docs/trunk/gdp-handbook.
